case_name: Electricity Board of Rajasthan v. Mohan Lal

facts.text: Electricity Board of Rajasthan constituted on 1st July 1957 under Electricity Supply Act 1948

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in this appeal is Electricity Board of Rajasthan, Jaipur  hereinafter referred to as the Board , a body companyporate companystituted on 1st July, 1957, under the Electricity  Supply  Act, 1948  No. 54 of 1948 .

facts.text: Before constitution of Board, electricity supply in Rajasthan controlled by Electrical and Mechanical Department of State Government

anchor.surface_text: Before the companystitution of the Board, the supply of electricity in the State of Rajasthan was being companytrolled directly by a department of the State Government named as the Electrical and Mechanical Department.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 Mohan Lal and respondents 4 to 14 were permanent employees of State Government as Foremen in Electrical and Mechanical Department

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1, Mohan Lal, as well as respondents 4 to 14 were all permanent employees of the State Government holding posts of Foremen in the Electrical and Mechanical Department.

facts.text: Services of employees including respondents provisionally placed at disposal of Board by Government notification on 12th February 1958 under section 78A of Act 54 of 1948

anchor.surface_text: On the companysti- tution of the Board, the services of most of the employees, including all these respondents, were provisionally placed at the disposal of the Board by a numberification issued by the Government on 12th February, 1958, purporting to exercise its powers under section 78A of Act 54 of 1948.

facts.text: Notification directed Board to frame new grades and service conditions, employees to opt to accept new or continue old or claim pension

anchor.surface_text: In this numberification a direction was included that the Board was to frame its own new grades and service companyditions under its regulations, and the employees, whose services were transferred to the Board, were to exercise option either to accept these new grades and service companyditions, or to companytinue ill their existing grades and service companyditions, except in regard to companyduct and disciplinary rules, or to obtain relief from Government service by claiming pension or gratuity as might be admissible on abolition of posts under the Rajasthan Service Rules.

facts.text: Board did not frame any new grades and service conditions up to time of litigation

anchor.surface_text: The Board, however, did number frame any new grades and service companyditions at least up to the time that the present litigation arose.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 deputed by State Government order dated 27th January 1960 to Public Works Department after working under Board for about two years

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 was, however, deputed by the State Government by its order dated 27th January, 1960, after having worked under the Board for a period of about two years, to the Public Works Department of the Government.

facts.text: On 10th August 1960, Government order indicated respondent No. 1 and respondents 4 to 14 treated as on deputation to the Board

anchor.surface_text: On 10th August, 1960, an order was made by the Government addressed to the Secretary of the Board indicating that respondent No. 1 as well as respondents 4 to 14 were to be treated as on deputation to the Board.

facts.text: On 24th November 1962, Public Works Department reverted respondent No. 1 to parent department from 1st December 1962, deputation extended till 25th July 1963

anchor.surface_text: On 24th November, 1962, the Public Works Department passed an order reverting respondent No. 1 to his parent department with effect from 1st December, 1962, but the period of deputation was later extended till 25th July, 1963.

facts.text: On 11th July 1963, respondent No. 1 reverted to Board and Board posted him as Foreman

anchor.surface_text: On 11th July, 1963, he was actually reverted to the Board from the Public Works Department, and the Board issued orders posting respondent No. 1 as a Foreman.

facts.text: While respondent No. 1 in Public Works Department, respondents 4 to 14 promoted by Board as Assistant Engineers

anchor.surface_text: In the interval, while respondent No. 1 was working in the Public Works Department, respondents 4 to 14 had been promoted by the Board as Assistant Engineers,

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 promoted to Assistant Engineer in Public Works Department

anchor.surface_text: while respondent No. 1 was promoted to work as Assistant Engineer in the Public Works Department.

facts.text: On reversion, respondent No. 1 claimed promotion as Assistant Engineer under Board as juniors promoted, request turned down by Board and State Government

anchor.surface_text: On his reversion, respondent No. 1 claimed that he was also entitled to be promoted as Assistant Engineer under the Board, because some of the other respondents promoted were junior to him, and, in the alternative, that, in any case, he was entitled to be companysidered for promotion. This request made by him to the Board as well as to the State Government was turned down

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed writ petition under Articles 226 and 227 in Rajasthan High Court claiming violation of Articles 14 and 16

anchor.surface_text: and, thereupon, respondent No. 1 filed a petition under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution in the High Court of Rajasthan. Respondent No. 1 claimed that he was entitled to equality of treatment with respondents 4 to 14, and, inasmuch as he had number been companysidered for promotion with them by the Board, the Board had acted in violation of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Board contested writ: respondent No. 1 never permanent servant of Board; Board not State under Article 12

anchor.surface_text: The Board companytested the petition on two grounds. The first ground was that respondent No. 1 had never become a permanent servant of the Board and never held any substantive post under it, so that he companyld number claim to be companysidered for promotion with respondents 4 to 14. The second ground was that the Board companyld number be held to be State as defined in Article 12 of the Constitution

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court rejected Board's grounds, quashed promotions of respondents 4 to 14, directed Board to consider promotions afresh including respondent No. 1, judgment dated May 14 1965 in D.B. Civil Miscellaneous Writ Petition No. 469 of 1963

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 14, 1965 of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Civil Mis- cellaneous Writ Petition No. 469 of 1963.

facts.text: Board appealed to Supreme Court by special leave, Civil Appeal No. 466 of 1966

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 466 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 14, 1965

facts.text: Supreme Court held respondent No. 1 was employee of Board like respondents 4 to 14, entitled to be considered for promotion on equality

anchor.surface_text: we are unable to hold that the High Court companymitted any error in holding that respondent No. 1 was in the service of the Board just as were respondents 4 to 14.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Board is 'State' under Article 12 of Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The Board was clearly an authority to which the provisions of Part III of the Constitution were applicable.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal with costs

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: In deputation order to PWD dated 27 January 1960, respondent No. 1 to retain lien in Power Department

anchor.surface_text: At that time, in the order posting him to the Public Works Department, it was laid down that he would retain his lien in the Power Department.

facts.text: High Court found Power Department refers to State Electricity Board

anchor.surface_text: We, however, found in the judgment of the High Court that the High Court attempted to gather the meaning of the expression Power Department by questioning the companynsel for the Board and the officer-in- charge of the Board who appeared before the High Court and was able to discover that there is numberPower Department existing as such and that this was just another name for the State Electricity Board.

facts.text: On reversion from PWD on 11 July 1963, Board posted respondent No. 1 as Foreman in Chambal Grid Sub-Station Udaipur against newly sanctioned post

anchor.surface_text: Even the Board itself, in its order dated 11th July, 1963, proceeded on the basis that respondent No. 1 had reverted from the Public Works Department and made a direction that, on reversion from that Department, he was posted as Foreman 1, Chambal Grid Sub-Station, Udaipur, against a newly sanctioned post.

facts.text: Respondents 4 to 14 treated as permanent employees by Board and promoted despite no permanent transfer order after provisional placement

anchor.surface_text: In the cases of these respondents also, there is numberhing to show that, after their services were provisionally placed at the disposal of the Board by the numberification dated 12th February, 1958, any order was passed permanently transferring them to the Board and, yet, they were treated as permanent employees of the Board.

facts.text: Since Board did not frame new service conditions, all respondents continued under old conditions from State service

anchor.surface_text: Since the Board did number frame any new grades or new service companyditions, it is clear that respondent No. 1 as well as respondents 4 to 14 companytinued to be governed by the old grade-, and service companyditions applicable to them when they were servants of the State Government

issues.text: Whether the Board had acted in violation of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution by not considering respondent No. 1 for promotion equally with respondents 4 to 14

anchor.surface_text: under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution in the High Court of Rajasthan. Respondent No. 1 claimed that he was entitled to equality of treatment with respondents 4 to 14, and, inasmuch as he had not been considered for promotion with them by the Board, the Board had acted in violation of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether respondent No. 1 had become a permanent servant of the Board and held any substantive post under it, so that he could claim to be considered for promotion with respondents 4 to 14

anchor.surface_text: The Board contested the petition on two grounds. The first ground was that respondent No. 1 had never become a permanent servant of the Board and never held any substantive post under it, so that he could not claim to be considered for promotion with respondents 4 to 14. The second ground was that the Board could not be held to be State as defined in Article 12 of the Constitution and, consequently no direction could be issued

issues.text: Whether the Board could be held to be 'State' as defined in Article 12 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The second ground was that the Board could not be held to be State as defined in Article 12 of the Constitution and, consequently no direction could be issued to the Board by the High Court under Art. 226 or Art. 227 of the Constitution on the basis that the actions of the Board had violated Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the principle of ejusdem generis applies to the interpretation of 'other authorities' in Article 12 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Courts fell into an error in applying the principle of ejusdem generis when interpreting the expression other authorities in Art. 12 of the Constitution, as they overlooked the basic principle of interpretation that, to invoke the application of ejusdem generis rule, there must be a distinct genus or category running through the bodies already named.

issues.text: Whether every constitutional or statutory authority is 'other authority' within Article 12

anchor.surface_text: The Board is, in my judgment, other authority within the meaning of Art. 12 of the Constitution. I am unable, however, to agree that every constitutional or statutory authority on whom powers are conferred by law is other authority within the meaning of Art. 12.

holdings.text: respondent No. 1 was in the service of the Board just as were respondents 4 to 14

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 was identically placed and, in these circumstances, we are unable to hold that the High Court committed any error in holding that respondent No. 1 was in the service of the Board just as were respondents 4 to 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government and Board treated respondent No. 1 as Board's employee through deputation orders, lien in Power Department (Board), reversion from PWD to Board posting, identical provisional transfer and promotions of respondents 4-14 without permanent orders

holdings.text: respondent No. 1 as well as respondents 4 to 14 continued to be governed by the old grade- and service conditions applicable to them when they were servants of the State Government

anchor.surface_text: Since the Board did not frame any new grades or new service conditions, it is clear that respondent No. 1 as well as respondents 4 to 14 continued to be governed by the old grade- and service conditions applicable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification required Board to frame new conditions but it did not, so old State service conditions continued for all identically placed employees

holdings.text: respondent No. 1 was entitled to be considered for promotion under the Board on the basis of equality with respondents Nos. 4 to 14

anchor.surface_text: All of them being governed by identical rules, it is clear that respondent No. 1 was entitled to be considered for promotion under the Board on the basis of equality with respondents Nos. 4 to 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Identical service conditions and status as Board employees required equal consideration for promotion under Articles 14 and 16

holdings.text: the High Courts fell into an error in applying the principle of ejusdem generis when interpreting the expression other authorities in Art. 12 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Courts fell into an error in applying the principle of ejusdem generis when interpreting the expression other authorities in Art. 12 of the Constitution, as they overlooked the basic

holdings.reasoning_summary: No distinct genus or category common to named bodies (Governments, Legislatures, local authorities); rule requires genus which is lacking

holdings.text: The expression other authorities is wide enough to include within it every authority created by a statute and functioning within the territory of India, or under the control of the Government of India

anchor.surface_text: This dictionary meaning of the word authority is clearly wide enough to include all bodies created by a statute on which powers are conferred to carry out governmental or quasigovernmental functions. The expression

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary meaning wide; supported by precedents (Ujjam Bai, Ramamurthi Reddiar); no narrowing needed; includes statutory bodies with governmental/quasi-governmental functions despite commercial activities (Arts 19(1)(g), 46, 298)

holdings.text: The Board was clearly an authority to which the provisions of Part III of the Constitution were applicable

anchor.surface_text: The Board was clearly an authority to which the provisions of Part III of the Constitution were applicable. We have already held earlier that, in dealing with the case of respondent No. 1, the Board

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory powers include governmental functions like directions enforceable criminally; not excluded by commercial nature

holdings.text: in dealing with the case of respondent No. 1, the Board did not treat him on terms of equality with respondents Nos. 4 to 14 and did not afford to him the opportunity for being considered for promotion

anchor.surface_text: We have already held earlier that, in dealing with the case of respondent No. 1, the Board did not treat him on terms of equality with respondents Nos. 4 to 14 and did not afford to him -the opportunity

holdings.reasoning_summary: Failed to consider equally despite identical circumstances, violating Articles 14 and 16

holdings.text: The High Court was, therefore, right in allowing the petition of respondent No. 1

anchor.surface_text: the High Court was, therefore, right in allowing the petition of respondent No. 1. The appeal is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correctly rejected Board's defenses and directed reconsideration of promotions including respondent No. 1

anchor.surface_text: The University of Madras v. Shantha Bai and Another 1 . The High Court, companysidering the question whether a University can be held to be local or other authority as defined in Art. 12, held These words must be companystrued ejusdem generis

precedents.case_name: University of Madras v Shantha Bai
precedents.cited_proposition: other authorities in Art. 12 to be construed ejusdem generis with Government or Legislature; universities exercising no governmental functions not included

precedents.citation: B. Devadas v. Tile Selection Committee for Admission of Students to the Karnatak Engineering College, and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: In B. Devadas v. Tile Selection Committee for Admission of Students to the Karnatak Engineering College, and Others 1 , the High Court of Mysore similarly held The term authority in the ordinary dictionary sense may companyprise number merely a person or a group of persons exercising governmental power, but also any person or group of persons who, by virtue of their position in relation to other person or persons, may be able to impose their will upon that other person or persons.

precedents.case_name: B Devadas v Tile Selection Committee
precedents.cited_proposition: authorities in Art. 12 refer to those exercising legislative or executive functions of State; non-political associations not included

precedents.citation: Krishan Gopal Ram Chand Sharma v. Punjab University and Another 1

precedents.case_name: Krishan Gopal Ram Chand Sharma v Punjab University
precedents.cited_proposition: Followed University of Madras; principle that other authorities ejusdem generis, universities not State

anchor.surface_text: the case of University of Madras  2   was followed and the principle laid down therein was approved and applied. On the basis of these decisions, and the principles laid down therein, it was urged that an examination of the provisions of the Electricity Supply Act will show that the Board is an autonomous body which cannot be held to be functioning as an agent of the Executive Government and, companysequently, it should be held that it is number State within the meaning of Art. 12 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: University of Madras v Shantha Bai
precedents.cited_proposition: Followed in Punjab HC case for ejusdem generis interpretation

anchor.surface_text: A.I.R. 1954 Mad. 67. named bodies, number can these bodies be placed in one single category on any rational basis. The doctrine of ejusdem generis companyld number, therefore, be, applied to the interpretation of the expression other authorities in this article. The meaning of the word authority given in Websters Third New International Dictionary, which can be applicable, is a public administrative agency or companyporation having quasi- governmental powers and authorised to administer a revenue- producing public enterprise.

precedents.case_name: University of Madras v Shantha Bai

precedents.citation: United Towns Electric Co., Ltd. v. Attorney-General for Newfoundland 5

anchor.surface_text: United Towns Electric Co., Ltd. v. Attorney-General for Newfoundland 5 , the Privy Council held that, in their opinion, there is numberroom for the application of the principle of ejusdem generis in the absence of any mention of a genus, since the mention of a single species- for example, water rates-does number companystitute a genus.

precedents.case_name: United Towns Electric Co Ltd v Attorney-General for Newfoundland
precedents.cited_proposition: No room for ejusdem generis without a distinct genus or category
precedents.cited_holding: there is numberroom for the application of the principle of ejusdem generis in the absence of any mention of a genus

precedents.citation: Smt,. Ujjam Bai v. State of Uttar Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: In Smt,. Ujjam Bai v. State of Uttar Pradesh 1 , Ayyangar, J., interpreting the words other authorities in Art. 12, held Again, Art. 12 winds up the list of authorities falling within the definition by referring to other authorities within the territory of India which cannot obviously be read as ejusdem generis with either the Government and the Legislatures or local authorities.

precedents.case_name: Ujjam Bai v State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: other authorities has wide amplitude, includes every authority created under statute functioning in India; not ejusdem generis
precedents.cited_holding: The words are of wide amplitude and capable of companyprehending every authority created under a statute and functioning within the territory of India or under the companytrol of the Government of India.

precedents.citation: K. S. Ramamurthi Reddiar v. The Chief Commissioner, Pondicherry and Another 2

anchor.surface_text: In K. S. Ramamurthi Reddiar v. The Chief Commissioner, Pondicherry and Another 2 , this Court, dealing with Art. 12, held Further, all local or other authorities within the territory of India include all authorities within the territory of India whether under the companytrol of the Government of India or the Governments of various States and even autonomous authorities which may number be under the companytrol of the Government at all.

precedents.case_name: K S Ramamurthi Reddiar v Chief Commissioner Pondicherry
precedents.cited_proposition: other authorities includes all constitutional/statutory authorities, even autonomous ones not under government control

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 was identically placed and, in these circumstances, we are unable to hold that the High Court committed any error in holding that respondent No. 1 was in the service of the Board just as were respondents 4 to 14.
The High Court was, therefore, right in allowing the petition of respondent No. The appeal is dismissed with companyts.
I am unable, however, to agree that every constitutional or statutory authority on whom powers are conferred by law is other authority within the meaning of Art. 12.
